and operations support areas, generally have terms of less than two years in duration. We have also entered into use agreements at each of the airports we serve that provide for
non-exclusive use of runways, taxiways and other facilities. Landing fees under these agreements are based on the number of landings and weight of the aircraft. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>29</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=31,EFW="2183318",CP="ALLEGIANT TRAVEL COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=754375,FOLIO='29',FILE='DISK112:[08ZAG1.08ZAG48801]DI48801A.;5',USER='SCARLSO',CD=';7-MAR-2008;13:21' -->
<A NAME="page_di48801_1_30"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
principal base of operations in Las Vegas is Terminal 1 at McCarran International Airport. We share the terminal with several other carriers. We currently lease two gates, and have
access to additional gates in the terminal. We believe we can operate ten departures per day per gate giving us current capacity to operate up to 20 departures per day on our leased gates and
additional departures per day on the gates we have access to use. While we currently have sufficient gate space to accommodate our near term requirements, we believe gate space may become more
difficult to obtain due to growth expected at McCarran. We also lease space at the cargo area on the field at McCarran which is used for line maintenance operations. We currently rely on the
availability of overnight aircraft parking space at the Las Vegas airport. However, due to the anticipated growth of McCarran, we may encounter difficulty in obtaining sufficient overnight aircraft
parking space in the future. Over time, this may result in our having to overnight more of our aircraft in other cities, which may increase our costs. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
principal base of operations in Orlando is Terminal B at Orlando Sanford International Airport. We are the only scheduled domestic carrier operating at Orlando Sanford International
Airport. The terminal has 12 gates, and we currently utilize up to three gates. We believe we have sufficient gate space to accommodate several years of growth at this airport. We also lease space in
a nearby cargo building that supports our line maintenance and commissary operations. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
use two gates at the St.&nbsp;Petersburg-Clearwater International Airport. We believe we have access to sufficient gate space to accommodate several years of growth at this airport. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
are the only carrier providing scheduled service at Phoenix-Mesa Gateway Airport in Phoenix based on currently published schedules. We believe we have access to sufficient
gate space to accommodate several years of growth at the airport. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
principal base of operations in Ft. Lauderdale is Terminal 2 at Ft. Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport. We have non-exclusive use of one gate at this airport.
While we have sufficient gate space to accommodate our near-term requirements, gate space at Ft. Lauderdale is at a premium, as is space for parking aircraft overnight and operational
space in general. While we believe that we will be able to accommodate our near-term Ft. Lauderdale growth plans, the space constraints may limit our growth or operations in the future. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
primary corporate offices are located in Las Vegas, where we lease 16,225 square feet of space under a lease that expires in June 2009. We also lease 18,500 square feet of office
space near the airport where our maintenance, in-flight and training staff are located, under a lease that expires in September 2010. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
May 2007, we entered into a lease for approximately 58,000 square feet of office space in a building to be constructed in Las Vegas, Nevada. We will combine all of our Las Vegas
off-airport operations into this office and the landlord has agreed to assume the balance of our two existing leases in Las Vegas. We expect to be able to occupy the new office as early as
May 2008. The lease has a ten-year term with two five-year renewal options, but we have the right to terminate the lease after seven years and the right to purchase the
building from the landlord after the third year of the lease. The initial base rental is approximately $1.3&nbsp;million per year and is subject to escalation. We are also responsible for our share
of common area maintenance charges. The landlord is a partnership in which certain of our officers and directors own significant interests as limited partners. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
also lease 5,000 square feet of space in Reno, Nevada, for our call center under a month to month lease and additional space near the Las Vegas airport for our commissary and parts
warehouse, under a lease that expires in August 2009. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>30</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_di48801_1_31"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> <A NAME="di48801_item_3._legal_proceedings"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_di48801_3"> </A>
Item&nbsp;3.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Legal Proceedings    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We are subject to certain legal and administrative actions we consider routine to our business activities. We believe the ultimate outcome of any pending legal or
administrative matters will not have a material adverse effect on our financial position, liquidity or results of operations. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> <A NAME="di48801_item_4._submission_of___di402390"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_di48801_4"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Not Applicable. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> <A NAME="dk48801_item_5._market_for_registrant___ite04645"> </A>

common stock in depository or nominee form. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Dividend Policy  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other than distributions paid or to be paid to our owners to defray the income taxes payable by them with respect to our taxable income while we were a
pass-through entity for income tax purposes, we have not declared or paid any dividends on our equity since our inception. We do not intend to pay any dividends on our common stock in the
foreseeable future. We currently intend to retain our future earnings, if any, to finance the further expansion and continued growth of our business. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>32</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=34,EFW="2183318",CP="ALLEGIANT TRAVEL COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=339287,FOLIO='32',FILE='DISK112:[08ZAG1.08ZAG48801]DK48801A.;18',USER='JHILL',CD='11-MAR-2008;15:15' -->
<A NAME="page_dk48801_1_33"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Use of Proceeds from Initial Public Offering  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On December&nbsp;13, 2006, we consummated the initial public offering of our common stock, $0.001 par value. The shares of common stock sold in the offering
were registered under the Securities Act of 1933, as amended, on a Registration Statement (Registration No.&nbsp;333-134145) that was declared effective by the Securities and Exchange
Commission on December&nbsp;8, 2006. The aggregate net proceeds to us from the offering were approximately $94.5&nbsp;million after deducting underwriting discounts and commissions paid to the
underwriters and other expenses incurred in connection with the offering. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Approximately
$0.9&nbsp;million of the proceeds were applied to the repayment of debt owed to our chief executive officer and chairman of the board. No other portion of the proceeds
from the offering was paid, directly or indirectly, to any of our officers or directors or any of their associates, or to any persons owning ten percent or more of our outstanding common stock or to
any of our affiliates. We have invested the remaining net proceeds in short-term, investment-grade, interest bearing instruments, pending their use to fund working capital and capital
expenditures, including capital expenditures related to the purchase of aircraft. As of December&nbsp;31, 2007, we have used $42.1&nbsp;million of the proceeds of our initial public offering for
capital expenditures. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Our Repurchases of Equity Securities  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table reflects our repurchases of our common stock during the fourth quarter of 2007. All stock repurchases were made from employees who received
restricted stock grants simultaneously with our initial public offering in December 2006. All stock repurchases were made at the election of each employee pursuant to an offer to repurchase by the
Company. The stock repurchases consisted of all or a portion of the restricted stock grant vesting in December 2007. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dk48801_issuer_purchases_of_equity_securities"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Stock Price Performance Graph  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following graph compares the cumulative total stockholder return on our common stock with the cumulative total return on the Nasdaq Composite Index and the
AMEX Airline Index for the period beginning on December&nbsp;8, 2006 (the date our common stock was first traded) and ending on the last day of 2007. The graph assumes an investment of $100 in our
stock and the two indices, respectively, on December&nbsp;8, 2006, and further assumes the reinvestment of all dividends. The December&nbsp;8, 2006 stock price used for our stock is the initial
public offering price. Stock price performance, presented for the period from December&nbsp;8, 2006 to December&nbsp;31, 2007, is not necessarily indicative of future results. </FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
number of weighted average diluted shares outstanding for purposes of calculating 2005 earnings per share includes our redeemable convertible preferred shares as if converted on a
one-for-one basis into common shares. The dilutive effect of common stock subject to outstanding options and warrants to purchase shares of common stock for 2005 is not
material. The dilutive effect of common stock subject to unvested restricted stock for 2006 was not material. </FONT></DD></DL>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>36</FONT></P>

<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=38,EFW="2183318",CP="ALLEGIANT TRAVEL COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=1032660,FOLIO='36',FILE='DISK112:[08ZAG1.08ZAG48801]DK48801A.;18',USER='JHILL',CD='11-MAR-2008;15:15' -->
<A NAME="page_dk48801_1_37"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following terms used in this section and elsewhere in this annual report have the meanings indicated below: </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;"</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>Available seat miles</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>" or "</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>ASMs</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>" represents the number of seats available for passengers
multiplied by the number of miles the seats are flown. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;"</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>Average fuel cost per gallon</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>" represents total aircraft fuel expense divided by the total number of fuel gallons consumed. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;"</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>Average stage length</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>" represents the average number of miles flown per flight. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;"</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>Load factor</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>" represents the percentage of aircraft seating capacity that is actually utilized (revenue passenger miles divided by
available seat miles). </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;"</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>Operating expense per ASM</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>" or "</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>CASM</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>" represents operating expenses divided by available
seat miles. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;"</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>CASM, excluding fuel</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>" represents operating expenses, less aircraft fuel, divided by available seat miles. Although CASM, excluding fuel
is not a calculation based on generally accepted accounting principles and should not be considered as an alternative to Operating Expenses as an indicator of our financial performance, this statistic
provides management and investors the ability to measure and monitor our cost performance absent fuel price volatility. Both the cost and availability of fuel are subject to many economic and
political factors and therefore are beyond our control. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;"</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>Operating revenue per ASM</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>" represents operating revenue divided by available seat miles. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;"</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>Revenue passengers</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>" represents the total number of passengers flown on all flight segments. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;"</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>Revenue passenger miles</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>" or </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>"RPMs"</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> represents the number of miles flown by revenue
passengers. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>"Yield"</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> represents scheduled service revenue divided by scheduled service revenue passenger miles. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>37</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_dm48801_1_38"> </A>


<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"Black" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"font-family:times;" -->


 </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> <A NAME="dm48801_item_7._management_s_discussio__ite03668"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dm48801_1"> </A>
Item&nbsp;7.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>The following discussion and analysis presents factors that had a material effect on our results of operations during the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2007, 2006 and 2005. Also discussed is our financial position as of December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006. You should read this discussion in conjunction with our consolidated
financial statements, including the notes thereto, appearing elsewhere in this annual report. This discussion and analysis contains forward-looking statements. Please refer to the section entitled
"Special Note About Forward-Looking Statements" for a discussion of the uncertainties, risks and assumptions associated with these statements.</I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Overview  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Who We Are.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We are a leisure travel company. The focus of our business is a low-cost passenger airline marketed
to leisure travelers in small cities. Our business model emphasizes low operating costs, diversified revenue sources, and the transport of passengers from small cities to leisure destinations. Our
route network, pricing philosophy, product offering and advertising are all intended to appeal to leisure travelers and make it attractive for them to purchase air travel and related services from us. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
provide service primarily to Las Vegas (Nevada), Phoenix (Arizona), Ft. Lauderdale (Florida), Orlando (Florida), and Tampa/St.&nbsp;Petersburg (Florida), five of the most popular
leisure destinations in the United States. We have positioned our business to take advantage of current lifestyle and demographic trends in the U.S. we believe are positive drivers for the leisure
travel industry. The most notable demographic shift occurring in the U.S. is the aging of the baby boomer generation as they enter their peak earning years and have more time and disposable income to
spend on leisure travel. We believe a large percentage of our customers fall within the baby boomer demographic and we target these customers through the use of advertisements in more than 300 print
circulations. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Fleet.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table sets forth the number and type of aircraft in service and operated by us at the dates
indicated: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(a)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Aircraft
owned includes aircraft subject to capital leases as follows: December&nbsp;31, 2007&#151;7; December&nbsp;31, 2006&#151;5; December&nbsp;31,
2005&#151;1. </FONT></DD></DL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Markets.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our scheduled service consists of limited frequency nonstop flights into leisure destinations
from small cities. As of December&nbsp;31, 2007, we offered scheduled service from 53 small cities primarily into Las Vegas, Phoenix, Ft. Lauderdale, Orlando, and Tampa/St.&nbsp;Petersburg,
including seasonal service. The following shows the number of destinations and small cities served as of the dates indicated: </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our Fiscal Year.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We operate on a calendar year ending on the last day in December. For convenience, we refer to the fiscal
years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007, December&nbsp;31, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005 as 2007, 2006 and 2005, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>38</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=40,EFW="2183318",CP="ALLEGIANT TRAVEL COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=1038954,FOLIO='38',FILE='DISK112:[08ZAG1.08ZAG48801]DM48801A.;12',USER='SCARLSO',CD=';7-MAR-2008;13:21' -->
<A NAME="page_dm48801_1_39"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Our Operating Revenue  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our operating revenue comprises both air travel on a stand-alone basis and bundled with hotels, rental cars and other travel-related services. We believe our
diversified revenue streams distinguish us from other U.S. airlines and other travel companies. </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Scheduled service revenue.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;Scheduled service revenue consists of nonstop flights between our leisure
destinations and small cities.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Fixed fee contract revenue.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;Our fixed fee contract revenue consists largely of fixed flying agreements with
affiliates of Harrah's Entertainment&nbsp;Inc. that provide for a predictable revenue stream. We also provide charter service on a seasonal and ad hoc basis to Harrah's and others.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Ancillary revenue.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;Our ancillary revenue is generated from the sale of hotel rooms, rental cars, advance seat
assignments, in-flight products and other items sold in conjunction with our scheduled air service. We recognize our ancillary revenues net of amounts paid to wholesale providers, travel
agent commissions and credit card processing fees.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Other revenue.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;Other revenue is generated from leased out aircraft and flight equipment. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Seasonality.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our business is seasonal in nature with traffic demand historically being lowest in the third quarter and
highest in the first quarter. Our operating revenue is largely driven by perceived product value, advertising and promotional activities and can be adversely impacted during periods with reduced
discretionary leisure travel spending, such as the back-to-school season. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Our Operating Expenses  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A brief description of the items included in our operating expense line items follows. Our cost structure is highly variable as we consider our fixed costs to
have represented only 3.92&cent; of our operating expense per available seat mile ("CASM") in 2007, or 47.9% of our 2007 operating expenses. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft fuel expense.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft fuel expense includes the cost of aircraft fuel, fuel taxes, into plane fees and airport fuel
flowage, storage or through-put fees. Under all of our fixed fee flying agreements, we are reimbursed by our customers if fuel exceeds a pre-determined cost per gallon, and
these reimbursements are netted against fuel expense. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Salary and benefits expense.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Salary and benefits expense includes wages and salaries as well as expenses associated with
employee benefit plans and employer payroll taxes. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Station operations expense.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Station operations expense includes the fees charged by airports for the use or lease of airport
facilities and fees charged by third party vendors for ground handling services and commissary expenses. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Maintenance and repairs expense.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Maintenance and repairs expense includes all parts, materials and spares required to
maintain our aircraft. Also included are fees for repairs performed by third party vendors. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sales and marketing expense.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sales and marketing expense includes all advertising, promotional expenses, travel agent
commissions, and credit card discount fees associated with sale of scheduled service. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft lease rentals expense.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft lease rentals expense consists of the cost of leasing aircraft which are operated
under operating leases with third parties. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation and amortization expense.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This expense includes the depreciation of all fixed assets, including aircraft that we
own, and amortization on aircraft that we operate under capital leases. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>39</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=41,EFW="2183318",CP="ALLEGIANT TRAVEL COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=437156,FOLIO='39',FILE='DISK112:[08ZAG1.08ZAG48801]DM48801A.;12',USER='SCARLSO',CD=';7-MAR-2008;13:21' -->
<A NAME="page_dm48801_1_40"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other expense.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other expense includes the cost of passenger liability insurance, aircraft hull insurance, and all other
insurance policies except for employee welfare insurance. Additionally, this expense includes employee bonuses, travel and training expenses for crews and ground personnel, facility lease expenses,
professional fees, personal property taxes and all other administrative and operational overhead expenses not included in other line items above. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Trends and Uncertainties Affecting Our Business  </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We believe our financial success is driven by variable factors that affect airlines and their markets, and by trends affecting the travel industry. The following
discussion describes certain key factors we believe may affect our future performance. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Demographics and Consumer Behavior  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The airline industry is influenced by lifestyle and demographic trends, and the performance of the broader U.S. economy. We believe the current demographic and
lifestyle trends are positive drivers of the leisure travel industry. The aging of the baby boomers as they enter their peak earning years with more disposable income has had a positive impact on
growing consumer demand for leisure travel. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Aircraft Fuel  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The airline industry is heavily dependent on the use of jet fuel and fuel costs represent a significant portion of the total operating expenses for airlines. Fuel
costs have been subject to wide price fluctuations. Fuel availability is also subject to periods of market surplus and shortage and is affected by demand for heating oil, gasoline and other petroleum
products. The cost and future availability of fuel cannot be predicted with any degree of certainty. In the fourth quarter of 2007, our average cost per gallon was $2.64 compared to $2.32 for the
third quarter of 2007. Partly in response to these recent higher fuel costs, we eliminated service on eight long-haul routes and reduced frequency on other long-haul routes as
of December&nbsp;31, 2007. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Labor  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The airline industry is heavily unionized and the wages and benefits of unionized airline industry employees are determined by collective bargaining agreements.
Conflicts between unionized airlines and their unions can lead to work slowdowns or stoppages. We currently have a non-unionized work force and are not subject to collective bargaining
agreements at the present time. Our pilots and flight attendants have formed in-house associations to negotiate matters of concern with us. Further attempts are possible to unionize our flight
attendants as the waiting period required by the National Mediation Board (NMB) has elapsed since the prior rejection of union representation on December&nbsp;4, 2006. If our employees were to
unionize in the future and we were unable to reach agreement on the terms of their collective bargaining agreement, or we were to experience wide-spread employee dissatisfaction, we could
be subject to work slowdowns
or stoppages. In addition, we may be subject to disruption by organized labor groups protesting our non-union status. Any of these events could have an adverse effect on our future
results. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Competition  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The airline industry is highly competitive. Passenger demand and fare levels have historically been influenced by, among other things, industry capacity and
pricing actions taken by other airlines. The principal competitive factors in the airline industry are fare pricing, customer service, routes served, flight schedules, types of aircraft, safety record
and reputation, code-sharing relationships, and frequent flyer programs. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>40</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>2007 Compared to 2006  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Summary  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We recorded total operating revenue of $360.6&nbsp;million, income from operations of $44.1&nbsp;million and net income of $31.5&nbsp;million for 2007. By
comparison, in 2006, we recorded total operating revenue of $243.4&nbsp;million, income from operations of $22.6&nbsp;million and net income of $8.7&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of December&nbsp;31, 2007, we had a fleet of 35 aircraft with 32 in service compared with a fleet of 26 aircraft with 24 in service as of December&nbsp;31, 2006. The growth of our
fleet enabled a 34.6% increase in available seat miles ("ASMs") for 2007 compared to 2006 as departures increased by 43.4% and average stage length decreased by 6.2%. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Scheduled
service ASMs&nbsp;in 2007 represented 88.6% of total ASMs&nbsp;compared to 86.2% in 2006 as scheduled service ASMs&nbsp;increased by 38.4% while fixed fee contract flying
ASMs&nbsp;increased by 11.3%. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Operating Revenue  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our operating revenue increased 48.2%, or $117.2&nbsp;million, to $360.6&nbsp;million in 2007 from $243.4&nbsp;million in 2006. This was driven by a 39.5%
increase in total system revenue passenger miles ("RPMs") and a 10.0% increase in revenue per ASM ("RASM"). </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Scheduled service revenue.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Scheduled service revenue increased 45.2%, or $80.6&nbsp;million, to
$258.9&nbsp;million in 2007 from $178.3&nbsp;million in 2006 due to a 42.5% increase in scheduled service RPMs.&nbsp;Yield increased 1.9% year-over-year in 2007 due to a
8.3% shorter scheduled stage length offset by the dilutive effect of introductory pricing on 12 new routes to Las Vegas, eight new routes to Orlando and four new routes to Tampa/St.&nbsp;Petersburg
that started during 2007. Introductory pricing for routes to our two new leisure destinations of Phoenix and Ft. Lauderdale in the fourth quarter 2007 also impacted yield in 2007. The decrease in
average stage length coupled with an increase in load factor of 2.4&nbsp;percentage points resulted in a 4.9% increase in scheduled service RASM from 7.21&cent; to 7.56&cent;. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Fixed fee contract revenue.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Fixed fee contract revenue increased 4.8%, or $1.7&nbsp;million, to
$35.4&nbsp;million in 2007 up from $33.7&nbsp;million in 2006. Fixed fee revenues increased principally because of increased flying for Harrah's Entertainment&nbsp;Inc. during 2007. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>41</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=43,EFW="2183318",CP="ALLEGIANT TRAVEL COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=978164,FOLIO='41',FILE='DISK112:[08ZAG1.08ZAG48801]DM48801A.;12',USER='SCARLSO',CD=';7-MAR-2008;13:21' -->
<A NAME="page_dm48801_1_42"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Ancillary revenue.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Ancillary revenue increased 107.9% to $65.0&nbsp;million in 2007 up from
$31.3&nbsp;million in 2006. The increase in ancillary revenue was due to a 55.5% increase in scheduled service passengers and a 33.6% increase in ancillary revenue per passenger from $16.11 to
$21.53 due primarily to the introduction of several new products. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other revenue.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Lease revenue was generated during 2007 of $1.3&nbsp;million related to the purchase
of eight engines while on lease to another airline. The engines were returned to us in October with no subsequent lease revenue recognized. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Operating Expenses  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our operating expenses increased by 43.4%, or $95.7&nbsp;million, to $316.5&nbsp;million in 2007 compared to $220.8 for 2006. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
general, our operating expenses are significantly affected by changes in our capacity, as measured by ASMs.&nbsp;The following table presents our unit costs, defined as CASM, for
the indicated periods. In addition, the table presents CASM, excluding fuel, which represents operating expenses, less aircraft fuel, divided by available seat miles. This statistic provides
management and investors the ability to measure and monitor our cost performance absent fuel price volatility. Both the cost and availability of fuel are subject to many economic and political factors
which are beyond our control. </FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft fuel expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft fuel expense increased 49.8%, or $50.6&nbsp;million, to
$152.1&nbsp;million in 2007 up from $101.6&nbsp;million in 2006. This change was due to a 37.6% increase in gallons consumed due primarily to a 34.6% increase in ASMs&nbsp;and an 8.5% increase
in the average cost per gallon to $2.30 per gallon during 2007 compared to $2.12 per gallon in 2006. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Salary and benefits expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Salary and benefits expense increased 45.2%, or $15.8&nbsp;million, to
$50.8&nbsp;million in 2007 up from $35.0&nbsp;million in 2006. This increase is largely attributable to a 39.5% increase in full-time equivalent employees to support our growth. We
employed approximately 1,180 full-time equivalent employees as of December&nbsp;31, 2007, compared to 846 full-time equivalent employees as of December&nbsp;31, 2006. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Station operations expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Station operations expense increased 35.6%, or $8.9&nbsp;million, to
$33.7&nbsp;million in 2007 compared to $24.9&nbsp;million in 2006. On a CASM basis, station operations has remained flat since the expense increase during 2007 was in line with our ASM growth. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Maintenance and repairs expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Maintenance and repairs expense increased by 32.3%, or
$6.3&nbsp;million, to $25.8&nbsp;million in 2007 up from $19.5&nbsp;million in 2006. The increase in maintenance and repairs expense is largely attributed to the cost from heavy maintenance
checks during 2007 compared to 2006 as both years we had 14 checks performed, along with increase in routine line maintenance from the growth of our fleet. Maintenance and repairs CASM declined 1.5%
as certain maintenance expenses were spread over a larger base of ASMs. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>42</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=44,EFW="2183318",CP="ALLEGIANT TRAVEL COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=959066,FOLIO='42',FILE='DISK112:[08ZAG1.08ZAG48801]DM48801A.;12',USER='SCARLSO',CD=';7-MAR-2008;13:21' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_do48801_1_43"> </A>


<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"Black" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"font-family:times;" -->


 </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sales and marketing expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sales and marketing expense increased 37.8%, or $3.5&nbsp;million, to
$12.8&nbsp;million in 2007 compared to $9.3&nbsp;million in 2006. The increase is a result of the advertising and credit card discount fees associated with the 45.2% increase in scheduled service
revenue. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft lease rentals expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft lease rentals expense decreased by 41.1%, or
$2.1&nbsp;million, to $3.0&nbsp;million in 2007 from $5.1&nbsp;million in 2006. On a CASM basis, aircraft lease rentals expense decreased 55.6% to 0.08&cent; in 2007 down from
0.18&cent; in 2006 due to an increase in the percentage of owned versus leased aircraft. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation and amortization expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation and amortization expense was $16.0&nbsp;million
in 2007 compared to $10.6&nbsp;million in 2006. The increase of 51.1% was primarily attributable to the number of in-service aircraft owned or subject to capital leases which increased
from 22 as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 to 28 as of December&nbsp;31, 2007, as well as the purchase of rotable parts to support the operating fleet. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other expense increased by 49.2% to $22.3&nbsp;million in 2007 compared to
$15.0&nbsp;million in 2006 due mainly to increased employee bonuses, aviation insurance, facilities and training expenses associated with our Company's growth, along with additional administrative
requirements resulting from being a public company. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Other (Income) Expense  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other (income) expense changed from a net other expense amount of $6.7&nbsp;million in 2006 to a net other income amount of $6.6&nbsp;million in 2007. This
change is primarily attributable to two factors: (1)&nbsp;a loss on fuel derivatives of $4.2&nbsp;million in 2006 compared to a gain on fuel derivatives of $2.6&nbsp;million in 2007 and
(2)&nbsp;an increase in interest income from $3.0&nbsp;million in 2006 to $9.2&nbsp;million in 2007 as a result of increased cash balances. We recognized a $1.6&nbsp;million loss in 2006 on
the mark-to-market adjustment for our open fuel derivative contracts and we recognized $2.6&nbsp;million in net losses for contracts settled in 2006. By contrast, we recognized a $1.7&nbsp;million
gain in 2007 on the mark-to-market adjustment for our open derivative contracts and we recognized $0.9&nbsp;million in net gains for contracts settled in 2007. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Income Tax Expense  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income tax expense for 2007 was $19.2&nbsp;million as our effective income tax rate for the period was 37.9%. Prior to our reorganization into a corporation at
the time of our initial public offering on December&nbsp;13, 2006, we did not pay corporate federal income tax at the entity level and therefore, we did not incur any federal income tax prior to the
initial public offering date. The income tax expense for 2006 was impacted by a $6.4&nbsp;million charge to recognize deferred tax liabilities due to the tax reorganization carried out in connection
with our initial public offering. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>2006 Compared to 2005  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Summary  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We recorded total operating revenue of $243.4&nbsp;million, income from operations of $22.6&nbsp;million and net income of $8.7&nbsp;million for 2006. By
comparison, in 2005, we recorded total operating revenue of $132.5&nbsp;million, income from operations of $8.5&nbsp;million and net income of $7.3&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of December&nbsp;31, 2006, we had a fleet of 26 aircraft with 24 in service compared with a fleet of 22 aircraft with 17 in service as of December&nbsp;31, 2005. The growth of our
fleet enabled a 71.5% increase in available seat miles for 2006 compared to 2005 as departures increased by 72.4% and average stage length decreased by 1.1%. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>43</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=45,EFW="2183318",CP="ALLEGIANT TRAVEL COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=982171,FOLIO='43',FILE='DISK112:[08ZAG1.08ZAG48801]DO48801A.;11',USER='SCARLSO',CD=';7-MAR-2008;13:21' -->
<A NAME="page_do48801_1_44"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Substantially
all of our ASM growth in 2006 compared to 2005 was in scheduled service which represented 86.2% of total ASMs&nbsp;in 2006 compared to 77.3% in 2005. Fixed fee contract
flying ASMs&nbsp;increased by 4.3%, and scheduled service ASMs&nbsp;increased by 91.2%. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Operating Revenue  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our operating revenue increased 83.7%, or $110.9&nbsp;million, to $243.4&nbsp;million in 2006 from $132.5&nbsp;million in 2005. This was driven by a 73.8%
increase in RPMs&nbsp;and a 7.2% increase in RASM. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Scheduled service revenue.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Scheduled service revenues increased 96.7%, or $87.7&nbsp;million, to
$178.3&nbsp;million in 2006 from $90.7&nbsp;million in 2005 due to a 93.9% increase in scheduled service RPMs.&nbsp;Yield increased 1.4% in 2006 versus 2005 due to a 3.7% shorter scheduled stage
length and the dilutive effect of introductory pricing on 11 new routes to Las Vegas, nine new routes to Orlando and 12 new routes to Tampa/St.&nbsp;Petersburg started during 2006. The decrease in
average stage length coupled with an increase in load factor of 1.1&nbsp;percentage points resulted in a 2.9% increase in scheduled service RASM from 7.01&cent; to 7.21&cent;. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Fixed fee contract revenue.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Fixed fee contract revenues increased 10.1%, or $3.1&nbsp;million, to
$33.7&nbsp;million in 2006 up from $30.6&nbsp;million in 2005. Revenues increased because of a short-term contract running from May through August 2006. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Ancillary revenue.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Ancillary revenues increased 179.2% to $31.3&nbsp;million in 2006 up from
$11.2&nbsp;million in 2005. The increase in ancillary revenue was due to a 100.2% increase in scheduled service passengers and a 39.5% increase in ancillary revenue per passenger from $11.55 to
$16.11 due primarily to the sale of several new products. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Operating Expenses  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our operating expenses increased by 78.1%, or $96.8&nbsp;million, to $220.8&nbsp;million in 2006 up from $124.0&nbsp;million during the same period in 2005. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following table represents our unit costs, CASM, for the indicated periods: </FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft fuel expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft fuel expense increased 93.2%, or $49.0&nbsp;million, to
$101.6&nbsp;million in 2006 up from $52.6&nbsp;million in 2005. This change was due to a 70.3% increase in gallons consumed and a 13.4% increase in the average cost per gallon to $2.12 per gallon
during 2006 compared to $1.87 in 2005. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Salary and benefits expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Salary and benefits expense increased 60.9%, or $13.2&nbsp;million, to
$35.0&nbsp;million in 2006 up from $21.7&nbsp;million in 2005. This increase is largely attributable to a 41.9% </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>44</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=46,EFW="2183318",CP="ALLEGIANT TRAVEL COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=449609,FOLIO='44',FILE='DISK112:[08ZAG1.08ZAG48801]DO48801A.;11',USER='SCARLSO',CD=';7-MAR-2008;13:21' -->
<A NAME="page_do48801_1_45"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>increase
in full-time equivalent employees to support our growth. We employed approximately 846 full-time equivalent employees as of December&nbsp;31, 2006, compared to 596
full-time equivalent employees as of December&nbsp;31, 2005. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Station operations expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Station operations expense increased 76.5%, or $10.8&nbsp;million, to
$24.9&nbsp;million in 2006 compared to $14.1&nbsp;million in 2005. The increase in station operations expense exceeded the 72.4% increase in departures contributing to an increase of 3.6% in
station operation expenses on a CASM basis. The increase in unit station operations expense was driven by a large number of new station openings, particularly in the fourth quarter of 2006, which
outweighed an increase in the proportion of scheduled flying, which generally has a lower station operations expense per departure relative to fixed fee flying. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Maintenance and repairs expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Maintenance and repairs expense increased by 115.9%, or
$10.5&nbsp;million, to $19.5&nbsp;million in 2006 up from $9.0&nbsp;million in 2005. Maintenance and repairs CASM increased 25.9% as increased maintenance expense outpaced the increase in
aircraft utilization. The increase in maintenance and repairs expense is largely attributed to heavy maintenance checks on 14 aircraft during 2006 versus four heavy checks during 2005 and the
substantially larger fleet as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 when compared to 2005. Additionally, in 2006 we had a significant increase in the number of heavy engine overhauls over 2005 due to a
significant year-over-year increase in the number of unplanned maintenance as a result of engine foreign object damage. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sales and marketing expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sales and marketing expense increased 65.2%, or $3.7&nbsp;million, to
$9.3&nbsp;million in 2006 compared to $5.6&nbsp;million in 2005. On a CASM basis, sales and marketing expense declined 5.9% primarily due to the elimination of travel agency commissions for air
only sales, a decrease in credit card processing fees and an increase in the percentage of sales through our website, our lowest cost distribution channel. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft lease rentals expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft lease rentals expense increased by 2.3%, or
$0.1&nbsp;million, to $5.1&nbsp;million in 2006 up from $5.0&nbsp;million in 2005. On a CASM basis, aircraft lease rentals expense decreased 40.0% to 0.18&cent; in 2006 down from
0.30&cent; in 2005 due to an increase in the percentage of owned versus leased aircraft and the benefits of higher aircraft utilization. In 2006, average block hours for aircraft in service
increased 9.7%, or 18&nbsp;hours, to 202.7&nbsp;hours per month compared to 184.7&nbsp;hours in 2005. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation and amortization expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation and amortization expense was $10.6&nbsp;million
in 2006 compared to $5.1&nbsp;million in 2005, an increase of 108.0% as the number of in-service aircraft owned or subject to capital leases increased from nine as of December&nbsp;31,
2005 to 22 as of December&nbsp;31, 2006. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other expense increased by 37.2% to $15.0&nbsp;million in 2006 compared to
$10.9&nbsp;million in 2005 due mainly to increased aviation insurance, administrative, facilities and training expenses associated with our company's growth. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Other (Income) Expense  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other expense increased from $1.2&nbsp;million in 2005 to $6.7&nbsp;million in 2006. This change was attributable to three factors: (1)&nbsp;net gain on
fuel derivatives of $0.6&nbsp;million in 2005 compared to a loss of $4.2&nbsp;million in 2006, (2)&nbsp;an increase in interest expense from $3.0&nbsp;million in 2005 to $5.5&nbsp;million in
2006 relating to interest on aircraft purchased and acquired under capital leases during the period and (3)&nbsp;an increase in interest income from $1.2&nbsp;million in 2005 to
$3.0&nbsp;million in 2006 as a result of increased cash and short-term investment balances. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
fuel derivative contracts do not qualify for hedge accounting under Statement of Financial Standards No.&nbsp;133, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Accounting for Derivative Instruments and
Hedging Activities</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. Therefore, we recognize </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>45</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=47,EFW="2183318",CP="ALLEGIANT TRAVEL COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=914560,FOLIO='45',FILE='DISK112:[08ZAG1.08ZAG48801]DO48801A.;11',USER='SCARLSO',CD=';7-MAR-2008;13:21' -->
<A NAME="page_do48801_1_46"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>changes
in the fair value of our derivatives when they occur, as a component of other (income) expense. We recognize gain or loss from a mark-to-market adjustment at the end of
each period, which estimates as of that date the future value of open contracts which will settle in subsequent periods. Gain or loss is also recognized as contracts settle and the amount can vary
depending on the market value of fuel at that time. We recognized a $2.4&nbsp;million loss in 2005 on the mark-to-market adjustment for our open fuel derivative contracts and
we recognized $3.0&nbsp;million in net gains for contracts settled in 2005. By contrast, we recognized a $1.6&nbsp;million loss in 2006 on the mark-to-market adjustment for
our open fuel derivative contracts and we recognized $2.6&nbsp;million in net losses for contracts settled in 2006. The change from an overall gain on fuel derivatives to a loss from 2005 to 2006 is
due to the fact that fuel prices predominantly increased during 2005 and decreased during the second half of 2006, along with an increase in the amounts hedged during 2006. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Income Tax Expense  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For all of 2005 and all but the last 18&nbsp;days of 2006 we operated as a limited liability company or subchapter&nbsp;S corporation. Under these structures,
we did not pay federal corporate income tax for these periods. Instead, the members of the limited liability company or stockholders of the subchapter&nbsp;S corporation were liable for income tax
on the taxable income as it affected their individual income tax returns. Accordingly, our income tax provision in 2005 reflects state taxes owed by us in certain states in which we operate. For the
last 18&nbsp;days of 2006, we operated as a subchapter&nbsp;C corporation, and we expect to operate as a subchapter&nbsp;C corporation for the foreseeable future. The income tax expense for 2006
was impacted by a $6.4&nbsp;million charge to recognize deferred tax liabilities due to the tax reorganization carried out in connection with our initial public offering. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do48801_liquidity_and_capital_resources"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do48801_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our primary sources of funds are cash provided by operations and cash provided by financing activities. Our primary uses of cash are for working capital, capital
expenditures and general corporate purposes. Historically, we have been able to fund our short-term needs for capital from cash generated from operations. Our long-term needs
for capital are generally for the purchase of additional aircraft. To the extent financing is not available on acceptable terms, we would apply our cash assets to the purchase of aircraft. If we do
not have sufficient cash assets available for this purpose at that time, then we would consider leasing aircraft or deferring their acquisition. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Current Liquidity  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our total cash, including cash and cash equivalents, restricted cash and short-term investments totaled $186.8&nbsp;million, $147.3&nbsp;million
and $58.2&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2007, 2006 and 2005, respectively. Restricted cash represents credit card deposits, escrowed funds under our fixed fee flying contracts, and cash
collateral against letters of credit required by hotel properties for guaranteed room availability, airports and certain other parties. Short-term investments represent marketable
securities which are available for sale. During 2007 and 2006, our restricted cash balances increased by $4.2&nbsp;million and $6.4&nbsp;million, respectively, as a result of increased letters of
credit issued to our hotel vendors. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under
our fixed fee flying contracts, we require our customers to prepay for flights to be provided by us. The prepayments are escrowed until the flight is completed. Prepayments are
recorded as restricted cash and a corresponding amount is recorded as air traffic liability. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating activities.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash flows provided by operations for 2007 were $74.0&nbsp;million compared
to $34.7&nbsp;million in 2006. This increase in cash flows provided by operations is primarily the result of increases in operating income and in passenger bookings for future travel. During 2006,
cash flows provided by operations decreased from $44.0&nbsp;million provided in 2005. This decrease was due to </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>46</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=48,EFW="2183318",CP="ALLEGIANT TRAVEL COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=784123,FOLIO='46',FILE='DISK112:[08ZAG1.08ZAG48801]DO48801A.;11',USER='SCARLSO',CD=';7-MAR-2008;13:21' -->
<A NAME="page_do48801_1_47"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>changes
in air traffic liability related to future travel and increased cash collateral requirements used to secure additional room capacity with our hotel partners offset by increases in net income,
noncash depreciation and amortization, and deferred income taxes related to the conversion from a limited liability company to a C-corporation. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investing activities.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash used by investing activities totaled $68.9&nbsp;million for 2007,
compared to $1.6&nbsp;million in 2006. Purchases of available for sale securities and capital expenditures for aircraft and equipment related to expanding our aircraft fleet constituted the primary
uses of cash for investing activities. During 2007, we used cash of $42.1&nbsp;million for the purchase of property and equipment and $21.3&nbsp;million for the purchase of available for sale
securities, net of maturities. The property and equipment purchases in 2007 included an equipment package made up of eight engines and one airframe, two aircraft previously under operating lease, two
aircraft purchased free and clear, and two other aircraft purchased with partial financing. During 2006, we expended $27.8&nbsp;million in cash for purchase of property and equipment and were
provided $26.2&nbsp;million in cash from the maturities of available for sale securities, net of purchases. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Financing activities.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash provided by financing activities totaled $9.0&nbsp;million for 2007,
compared to $75.9&nbsp;million in 2006. Financing activities in 2007 primarily consisted of the proceeds from our secondary offering of our stock of $22.3&nbsp;million, offset by debt repayments
related to aircraft financing
and capital lease obligations. During 2006, we generated cash from the issuance of common stock in connection with our initial public offering of $94.5&nbsp;million, net of offering expenses, which
was offset by debt repayments of $14.1&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Debt  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Of the 35 aircraft we have accepted delivery of as of December&nbsp;31, 2007, we had secured debt financing on 14 aircraft and capital lease financing on seven
aircraft. We financed the purchase of 14 aircraft with notes for an aggregate initial borrowed amount of $43.8&nbsp;million, which are scheduled to mature between 2008 and 2011. The equipment notes
bear interest at fixed rates between 6.0% and 9.0% with principal and interest payable monthly. Each note is secured by a first mortgage on the aircraft to which it relates. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
have a commitment to purchase two additional MD-88 aircraft with seller financing for delivery prior to the end of the second quarter of 2008. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Commitments and Contractual Obligations  </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table discloses aggregate information about our contractual cash obligations as of December&nbsp;31, 2007 and the periods in which payments are
due (in thousands): </FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Long-term
debt obligations include scheduled interest payments.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(2)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Operating
lease obligations include aircraft operating leases and leases of airport station property and office space. </FONT></DD></DL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>47</FONT></P>

<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=49,EFW="2183318",CP="ALLEGIANT TRAVEL COMPANY",DN="1",CHK=189847,FOLIO='47',FILE='DISK112:[08ZAG1.08ZAG48801]DO48801A.;11',USER='SCARLSO',CD=';7-MAR-2008;13:21' -->
